overlaySubtitle: For when your brain will not switch off
hook: Your baby is finally asleep. Your body is done. But your mind is loud, racing through every worst-case "what if."
imagePrompt: Flat vector illustration in soft pastels (coral, teal, cream). 3:4 aspect ratio. A tired new mom sits on the edge of a bed in a dim nursery, baby monitor on the nightstand, soft morning light coming through the window. The room is a little messy, but her shoulders look softer, one hand on her chest, eyes gently closed as she takes a slow breath. Abstract leaf shapes and gentle flowing lines in the background to suggest calming thoughts and slow breathing.
caption:
You are not the only mom lying awake, scrolling, googling, replaying the day and waiting for something to go wrong.

That knot in your chest. The tight jaw. The "I should be sleeping but I cannot" spiral.
That is anxiety, not failure.

You are not a bad mom.
You are a brand-new human caring for a brand-new human.
Your nervous system is just on maximum alert.

Here are 6 tiny tips for mom anxiety at night:
1. The "one square breath": Inhale for 4, hold 4, exhale 4, hold 4. Do this just 3 times. Not perfect. Just try.
2. Say one sentence out loud: "Right now, in this moment, my baby is safe enough and I am safe enough."
3. Put your phone on the other side of the room for 10 minutes. If you still want it after, you can get up and grab it.
4. Keep a "worry pad" by the bed. When a thought loops, write one messy line, close the notebook. You are allowed to leave it there.
5. Relax just your tongue and shoulders. Notice what drops when you do. Let your jaw feel heavy.
6. Choose one tiny anchor: a warm sip of water, a soft blanket, a hand on your heart. Tell your body, "We stand down now."

You do not have to fix all your anxiety tonight.
Even one small thing is enough.

Inside MomMirror, your 3-minute check-in gently walks you through:
- A deep grounding breath
- Naming the fear without judging it
- Choosing ONE tiny action, like a sentence to tell yourself or a place to relax your body

No lectures. No pressure. Just a softer voice than the one in your head.

You still have the same baby. The same night feeds. The same laundry pile.
But you?
You get to feel a little less on fire.
A little more like a person who happens to be a mom, not a robot who never gets to rest.

If tonight feels heavy, you do not have to power through it alone.
cta: Start my 3-minute check-ins and give my brain one softer place to land.

overlayTitle: 6 Calming Tips for "Is My Baby Okay?" Anxiety
overlaySubtitle: For the constant checking and re-checking
hook: You keep staring at your baby, checking their chest, googling every noise, afraid you will miss something and it will be your fault.
imagePrompt: Flat vector art, pastel coral and teal on cream background, 3:4 aspect ratio. A mom sits in a cozy chair by a bassinet, room a little cluttered. One hand rests lightly on the side of the bassinet while she looks away from it, eyes softer, taking a slow breath. Gentle plant shapes and soft circular lines behind her suggest safety and calm expanding outward. Overall feeling: same real-life mess, but less panic.
caption:
Your brain is doing laps around one thought: "If I do not watch them every second, something terrible will happen."

You listen for every breath.
You google every sound.
You replay every moment and ask, "Did I miss a sign?"

This is not you being dramatic.
This is you being a first-time mom with a nervous system on red alert.

You are not overreacting.
You are over-protecting because you care so much.
You are not broken. You are exhausted and scared.

Here are 6 tiny tips for "Is my baby okay?" anxiety:
1. The 3-breath check: Look, listen, lightly touch. Take 3 slow breaths while you do it. Then step back. The check is complete.
2. Set a "reassurance rule": "I will check once, not three times, before I sit down again." Be kind with it. It is a goal, not a test.
3. Create a short safety sentence: "Babies are noisy sleepers. Noise does not mean danger." Repeat it as often as you need.
4. Use a simple timer: When you put your baby down, set a 5–10 minute timer before the next check. Let the timer hold the worry for you.
5. Limit late-night Dr. Google. Choose 1 trusted source you check during the DAY, not at 2 a.m.
6. Put one hand on your heart and one hand on the crib/bassinet and say, "I am doing enough. I am allowed to blink."

Your baby does not need a perfect, always-alert robot.
They need a human.
And humans need breaks.

Inside MomMirror, your 3-minute check-in helps you:
- Catch the scary "what if" sentences
- Swap them for one kinder, truer sentence
- Choose one boundary with checking that still feels safe

It will not erase every fear.
But it will turn the volume down enough that you can sit, breathe, maybe even finish your tea while it is still warm.

You get to feel like a mom who cares deeply and also gets to rest her eyes.
You get to be present with your baby without your heart racing all day.
cta: Start my 3-minute check-ins and practice feeling safer, one tiny step at a time.

overlayTitle: 6 Tips for "I’m Not Doing This Right" Anxiety
overlaySubtitle: When every choice feels like the wrong one
hook: You second-guess every decision: feeding, sleep, diapers, visitors. Whatever you choose, the guilt shows up fast.
imagePrompt: Flat vector illustration, 3:4 aspect ratio, pastel coral and teal. A mom sits at a messy kitchen table with baby items and an open baby book/phone beside her. She gently closes the book or flips the phone face-down, takes a breath, and looks out a window with soft light coming in. Background has simple plant motifs and soft upward lines suggesting growth and self-trust.
caption:
Your thoughts sound like this:
"Did I feed them enough?"
"Should I have done tummy time longer?"
"Am I ruining their sleep already?"
"If I loved them enough, this would feel easier."

It is so heavy when every tiny decision feels like a test you are failing.

You are not a bad mom for feeling unsure.
You are a beginner at the hardest job on earth, with a baby who did not come with a clear manual.
Of course your brain is spinning.

Here are 6 tiny tips for "I am not doing this right" anxiety:
1. Try the "good enough" rule: Instead of asking, "Is this perfect?" ask, "Is this safe enough and loving enough for today?"
2. Limit opinions: Choose 1–2 trusted voices (a friend, a doctor, a guide). Everyone else goes on mute for now.
3. Give each decision a time box: "I will think about this for 10 minutes. Then I will pick something and try it for 24 hours."
4. Talk to yourself like a friend: What would you say to another new mom doing exactly what you are doing right now? Say that to yourself out loud.
5. Keep a "tiny wins" note on your phone: "Changed 6 diapers." "Fed baby even though I was tired." "Asked for help once." Read it when guilt gets loud.
6. Remind yourself: "Newborns need love and safety, not perfection." Whisper it every time you start to spiral.

You are learning.
So is your baby.
You get to be a work in progress and still be a good mom.

Inside MomMirror, your 3-minute check-in helps you:
- Notice the harsh words you are using on yourself
- Swap them for gentler, truer ones
- Spot one small win from today you keep overlooking

You still have the same crying spells, same cluster feeds, same piles of laundry.
But inside?
You stand a little taller.
You let yourself be "good enough" instead of "never enough."

You get to feel like a person who is allowed to figure it out, not a student waiting to be graded.
cta: Start my 3-minute check-ins and practice talking to yourself like someone you love.

overlaySubtitle: When you are up, the world is quiet, and your mind is not
hook: It is dark, everyone else is asleep, and you are feeding the baby with a tight chest and a brain that will not shut up.
imagePrompt: Flat vector art, 3:4 aspect ratio. Nighttime scene in soft navy, coral, and teal. A mom sits in a rocking chair holding or near a sleeping baby, a warm lamp casts gentle light. Around her, abstract stars and soft waves transition into leaves and morning light tones, suggesting moving from chaos to calm. The room is still a bit cluttered, but her face looks softer and more at ease.
caption:
3 a.m. has a special kind of loneliness.
It is just you, the baby, the glow of your phone, and a flood of thoughts:
"What if I never feel normal again?"
"What if I mess them up?"
"What if I disappear in this?"

You are not too much.
You are not weak.
You are tired, hormonal, healing, and carrying a whole human's future in your arms.
Of course your brain is loud.

Here are 6 tiny tips for 3 a.m. mom anxiety:
1. Name the hour: "This is 3 a.m. brain, not the whole truth." Night thoughts are louder, not more accurate.
2. Pick a simple grounding ritual: feel your feet on the floor, notice 3 things you can see, 3 things you can touch, 3 sounds you can hear.
3. Swap doom scrolling for one soft thing: a calming playlist, a comforting podcast, or just the sound of a fan. Nothing intense, nothing dramatic.
4. Light zone: keep one small, warm light. Bright, white light can trick your brain into full alert.
5. Micro-movement: roll your shoulders, stretch your neck, wiggle your toes. Tell your body, "We are safe enough. We can soften a little."
6. Future you note: whisper or type a message to tomorrow you: "You did it. You made it through another night." Read yesterday's if you have one.

You do not have to love the nights.
You just have to get through them.

Inside MomMirror, your 3-minute check-in is built for these moments:
- A few deep, guided breaths while you feed or rock
- A quick reframe of the scariest thought in your head
- One tiny, kind thing you will do for yourself when the sun comes up

No big routines.
No 20-step plans.
Just something small enough that even 3 a.m. you can handle it.

You still wake up tired.
The dishes are still in the sink.
But you feel a bit less like you are drowning in invisible fear.

You get to feel like a woman who is tired, yes, but also gentle with herself.
Not just a body holding everything together in the dark.
cta: Start my 3-minute check-ins and give your 3 a.m. brain a softer script.
